text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

1. In the first five years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting basis and family? Eight.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Twice a month.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Yes, Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Usually without invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually for dinner.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (Can't say) Was the term "make pollock" used, or was some other expression dropped in?

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Tea and cake or bread.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? All went out.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Not often.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

One shriveling bee in 1916.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Card parties and dances, but not seldom attended as we were not brought up that way.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. What about the times of the first and last which would win first on and off times.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by number from one home to another at definite times, once a week, once a month, etc.?
1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting? 
2. How many of these were bachelor's homes?
3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?
4. Were you often invited to other homes, or did most visiting done without an invitation?
5. What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?
6. Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
7. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
8. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?
9. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?
10. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?
11. Did you ever have "these" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?
12. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "reasons" were for, and how often they occurred.

Our story begins in 1916.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Card parties and dances but not all of them attended as we were not brought up that way.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Tell about the times of the first and what drove us just on and off town.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box seats, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, potlucks, etc., if you have not described these on the school Christmas tree, potlucks, etc.)

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. What dances were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

Was there ever any disrepancy between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

If was accepted by most everyone but me.

I didn't want to have the spaniel sit before my children, but some of them play cards sometimes.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. Include also the school Christmas tree, pictures, etc.

If you have not described these on the school Christmas tree, please do so.

Describe for social and Christmas parties and other parties.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. What was your first community hall built? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? A club, local, or private group, or county hall?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of home or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings?)

It was used by all the people who attended church and school at the same time.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8), and how did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

In the school house also neighbors came also

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

All women attended us can't say

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Stk

Was there any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was there any difference between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

It was accepted by most everyone but me.

I didn't want to have the example set before my children, but some of them play cards now.
3. What attempts at formality, or "socializing," do you remember in small towns such as yours and its main village, calling names, matters treated ceremonially.

13. Was the obituary known in your community? If so, describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments not wholesome but that were popular at parties and give approximate dates when you can when these changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Some of the people got lost on their way and circled a few times before it became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

They provided flowers for the dead, fuel for the sick and plenty of entertainment for all. Food supplies and treats for the children at various times helped the blind and the old ones, all who are in need.
13. Was the shivaree known in your community? 

Describe what you remember about shivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular in visiting or social life before the Reforms.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

Then was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

They provided flowers for the dead if sick and plenty of entertainment for all. They supplied and treated the children at various homes. Helped the blind.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving their name, when it was first organized, its activities, and the people who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included all or only one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire and handbooks connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

21. What games did boys play in summer? (Baseball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

22. What games did girls play in summer? (Skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

Did you often have radio lantern shows? Give dates if possible. 1928

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

Domestic life

Outdoor life
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name, whether it was a club (boy's, women's, young people), whether it is still active today, and purpose only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questions to include organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In the school house.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Dentrite, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Dad you often have magic lantern show? One Olive takes it possible, 1928

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer? (sand, marbles, fly kites, etc.)

What games did girls play in summer? (skipping rope, play house, etc.)

What games did children play in winter? (snowball fight, tag)

What games did children play in fall? (fall court, tag)

What games did children play in spring? (spring court, tag)
22. What winter games were played outside - for example, skating, snowballing, sledging, etc.? 

23. What winter games were played indoors in winter? Card games such as "Happy Families," "Whist," or others; checkers, chess, or other card games.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, or other objects or animals in the snow? Describe.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. That arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as whist, pinochle, checkers, dominoes, old maid, pitch and other card games? 
Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children hunt or play with animals or birds? 
Children had plenty of time for games but had to be careful not to disturb the animals.

25. What year was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 
Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district club, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

29. What were the arrangements made for smaller groups? 
Families and friends formed smaller groups.

30. What arrangements were made for eating? 
There was a general lunch, or did

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 
Tea, lemonade, pie, cake, etc.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 
Till dark or six. And then we went dancing.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. What did the children wear? (e.g., uniforms, etc.)

35. Describe any different kinds of pictures which you have seen in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school, or family affairs, activities, picnics, etc., held at various times.

36. Describe the events which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

38. How long did it continue?

39. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1910, giving dates of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

40. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

41. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

This is an indoor rink built about 1951 and used for curling.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

all floats for the children were provided free

Orange slices, candy, peanuts, and gum

a collection from the men paid for it.

every one went in willingly I think about so many

34. Name any different kinds of places which you knew of in the early days?

such as the large common or field, school or schoolhouse (usually called schoolhouse), plowlots, etc., when boys, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible,

give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sport or game which was most popular in your community in the early years.

telling who took part in the various games and sports (tennis, baseball, mostly young people).

37. For what year was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1910

How long did it continue? 1915-1920

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1910, giving date of organization, if possible, and tell whether they played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

baseball and hockey 1910

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

first played on lake rink built 1940

This is an indoor rink built about 1951 used for curling
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plant?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
    hockey hall of fame or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
    names you brought, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many
    books you bought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
    What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years at the school gate

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
46. Did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Yes

Did it grow out of or replace the nature community plant? Yes

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Mrs. Haywood Smith

When was the sports day usually held? (which month or any special day such as May 24th or July 4th)

47. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known literary clubs? No

48. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

49. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

50. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

51. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

52. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

53. Was there a school library? Yes

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

54. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material? Yes
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes

When was it started? Then started 1933

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

Family Harold and Alisterford (Out) Star

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

We lost interest in our home today as we didn't like recognizing names mentioned. We take the free press guide.

And to get the year's preview guide Over Country Guide.

On Chalmers' Chattawas & Home Journal

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you bought to the west with you do you still have?

All still have all the books we brought but the opening of the chimney fire (we ant it and forgot list).

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

One we didn't seem to find time to read much
52. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started?

Is it still in existence?

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who held its librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

53. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this area?

Family Harold and Watford (Cont.) Stan

54. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain ones and added others.

We first included an own home library at our place, recognizing the importance of owning a guide. Our Country Guide used to get the year's growing guide. Our Country Guide used to get the year's growing guide.

Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady's Home Journal material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

55. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

All still have all the books we brought but the opening of the chimney fire (we didn't find it) got lost.

56. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in this west a hardship? Explain.

One we didn't seem to find them. To need much
Musical Entertainment

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

Organ 1918 violin 1922 guitar 1930

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

I used to sing to my children a great deal.

60. In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

Yes, a measure of singing at the dances.

61. Was there a band in your community? Explain.

Yes, to come extend.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

No.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes.

Who started it? The Smith boys.

How many were in it? About four.

What instruments were included?

Drums, violins, saxophones, banjo.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

One uniform. I believe they practiced about once a week at their homes and they played just for local dances but not much lately.
Musical Instrument

56. What musical instruments did you bring with you?

57. Did any of your neighbors have a collection?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

Oregon 1918 - October 22, 1920

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

I used to sing to my children a great deal.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, parties, etc.) Describe.

Yes, a measure of singing at the church.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the house? (Ragged old Flag, God Bless America, etc.)

Smile To Night, Old Black Joe, Swing Low, Sweet Chariot, Wedding Hymn, A Downward and Upward, The Church House Band.

In the community? Folk songs, When Father joined the choir, Thirdly, If I could, I would, I'd go out with my wife through the town, The old folk music, or music of the country you came from, probably your home or community? Explain.

61. To come explain.

Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke, an anniversary, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

62. Was there a band in your community? Yes

Who started it? The Smith Boys

How long did it continue? 10 years

When was it started? 1930

63. How many were in it? 142

What instruments were included? Drums, Violin, Saxophone, Trumpet

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Our uniforms were blue. They practiced about twice a week at their homes and they played just for local dances but not much lately.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the world? If so, give name and date and place of public appearance.

65. Is there an important or famous person connected with the early days? What is the reason for this connection?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, coins, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, describe them briefly.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, flowering time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, roasting, making of pioneer days; not already mentioned.

One lady that used to win all ladies races also shuffling. Was unfortunate in having her home burnt down with two children in it. The district collected funds about 1910. That was to replace the home.
64. Has anyone from your community been well known or famous in the past?

65. Is there an important or famous building or place in your community now so connected with the early days? That is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Describe a few details of them.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how big it is, what it contains, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of ships, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

GENERAL

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music, flowers, etc.; not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)

One lady that used to own all Padda's property also died. Also unfortunate in having her home burnt down with two children in it. The district collected funds about 1910. The house was destroyed.
Oxford
